summary: The consensus approach for thermostability engineering of proteins involves using sequence alignments to identify stabilizing amino acid substitutions, leading to significant increases in unfolding temperatures without compromising catalytic activity.
key_claims: A consensus phytase with a Tm of 78.0°C was engineered from homologous mesophilic enzymes, showing a 15-22°C increase over parent phytases.
Optimized consensus phytases achieved Tm values up to 90.4°C through multiple amino acid exchanges affecting surface residues.

_title: The consensus concept for thermostability engineering of proteins
_abstract: Previously, sequence comparisons between a mesophilic enzyme and a more thermostable homologue were shown to be a feasible approach to successfully predict thermostabilizing amino acid substitutions. The `consensus approach' described in the present paper shows that even a set of amino acid sequences of homologous, mesophilic enzymes contains sufficient information to allow rapid design of a thermostabilized, fully functional variant of this family of enzymes. A sequence alignment of homologous fungal phytases was used to calculate a consensus phytase amino acid sequence. Upon construction of the synthetic gene, recombinant expression and purification, the first phytase obtained, termed consensus phytase-1, displayed an unfolding temperature (T m ) of 78.0³C which is 15^22³C higher than the T m values of all parent phytases used in its design. Refinement of the approach, combined with site-directed mutagenesis experiments, yielded optimized consensus phytases with T m values of up to 9
